companies ordinance 1962 (a.c.t.), ss. 61 (3), 221 (1) (h). the taxpayer gave 39,990 one dollar redeemable preference shares to a sydney public hospital, a charity. the taxpayer sought a deduction for $39,990 for the gift under s. 78 (1) (a) of the income tax assessment act 1936 . the preference shares were shares in a company specially set up for the purpose of the gift. the taxpayer purchased the shares for $39,990 and then gave them to the hospital. the hospital as shareholder was entitled to a dividend of 10 per cent per annum. this dividend was never paid. the shares in the company were redeemable upon notice from a shareholder. the evidence was that the taxpayer, a doctor with a long connexion with the hospital, was keen that the donation should be used towards cancer research. the commissioner disallowed the taxpayer's claim for a deduction, and the taxpayer successfully appealed to the supreme court of new south wales. the commissioner appealed. held, appeal allowed in part, that on the evidence there was a valid gift by the taxpayer. however, the gift should be valued for deduction purposes at only $24,000. even though the shares were redeemable, failure to redeem them after notice would not necessarily mean the shareholder could have the company wound up. ebrahimi v. westbourne galleries pty. ltd., (1973) ac 360 , referred to. the shares should be valued at $24,000. hearing sydney, 1981, august 11-12; october 30. 30:10:1981
